CatDescriptText: Edward Kearns, taxi-driver, Dormont and Elliott Fikel, service station attendant, Homewood were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, November 19, 1960, pg. C1 with question "Why do you think Negroes voted so heavily for Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat, for President, in last Tuesday's election?" Mr. Kearns' answer reads: "I think they voted for Kennedy, because of his stand on equal rights and employment."  Mr. Fikel's answer reads: "Because the Democrats and Kennedy are for everybody.  And, ever since the Republicans have been in office, we've had hard times.  Just what has the Eisenhower Administration done?  All he has done is gone golfing while little kids are being kept from attending school."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Edward Kearns standing next to taxi on Liberty Avenue with Thrift Drugs in background; Portrait of Elliott Fikel wearing zippered leather jacket, standing in front of shelves with automotive supplies
